This is the only location worth going to.  If you are the type that needs fancy extras on your burrito (ex. lettuce) or wants some other meat like chicken (GASP!) - you won't appreciate the pure beauty that is La Pasadita anyway...so go ahead and move along.   I used to always get the carne asada, until one time my friend accidentally brought me a barbacoa burrito.  I've never looked back.  Their barbacoa is so juicy and tender and delicious and perfectly flavored and yum yum yum yum yum.  I live nowhere near this place, and rarely find myself in the neighborhood.  But it is absolutely 100% worth a special trip every time. In fact, I think I may go there now.

First it must be noted that there are THREE (yes, three) La Pasadita's all next to each other on Ashland. 1141, 1140 and 1132. I finally found out through a friend of mine the mystery behind the three adjacent locations (she knows the owners). Apparently there are three brothers and each one runs a location. She didn't really elaborate beyond that but we all know how much the latinos love to be close to their familia so it sort of made sense to me.  Yeah, that's not exactly a mystery solved but I feel somewhat more enlightened now, don't you? I digress.  So the question is, does it make a difference which location I go to? Yes! 1140 is the way to go. And the only burrito you need is the carne asada. It's simple, it's clean (not really), it's juicy and amazing. Beef, cilantro and onion. That's it.  And for all you condiment lovers--RESTRAIN YOURSELF! Do NOT contaminate with sour cream or guacamole (they may make you go next door to get those anyways so save yourself a trip). Liken that to putting ketchup on your steak. It's a crime, really. The rich flavor of the beef and seasoning is heavenly. I have taken SO many friends here time and time again they have become believers too (with a couple exceptions--the non-meat lovers).  I will say that out of the maybe 20 times I've been here, they've had only one major off-day. I couldn't even finish my burrito as it was so boring.  I asked the cook if they changed their recipe because it doesn't taste the same. He said no, and then proceeded to blast the speakers next to us with mariachi music so loud that we couldn't speak. Yeah, he didn't like me insulting his carne.  But I forgave him.  Truly--this mexican hole-in-the-wall is a gem.  So yes, come here. It's a great after party spot at 2am but don't hesitate to take a burrito home with you after work. You won't be disappointed.

So, really, La Pasadita was NOT A-OK. However, the fact that I managed to show up to work without puking the next morning despite a plethora of shots of Jameson (oh why did that seem to be a great idea) helped this review go from eww to meh. Word. Steak burrito. Bleh. Boring meat. And cilantro. That's it? I was bored. Hungry. Drunk. But I didn't manage to eat the whole thing because it was rather gross. Oh, there must've been onions in there because when I woke up at 4 a.m. for a drink of water my mouth tasted of steak, onions and Jameson. But I didn't throw up. So, La Pasadita, you never will win in one of my Battle of the Burritos. Well, first of all,you've only got tacos and burritos on your menu. Really, I like to eat nachos with the fake melted cheese from a can when I've been drinking. The pork tacos from Las Traspasada (HOLY YUM) also work well. In the event you upgrade to some nachos like that, we might meet again. Otherwise I'm gonna hit up my Trader Joe's frozen burrito when I get home. It's got REAL BEANS IN IT. YUM. But yeah. Meh. Served as a way to put food in my belly and nothing more. I like my burritos saucy. Como mis hombres, natch.

PURE UNADULTERATED MEAT...three words to describe the experience at La Pasadita. The first burrito I have eaten in America with no filler just over a pound of meat wrapped in a tortilla with some fresh diced onion and cilantro for flavor.  The decor isn't for the faint of heart in the old yellow building with about 10 bar stools in the whole place and traditional Mexican music blaring from the speakers. The building is old and decrepit, but the character it has is what makes this place great. The menu features about 5 types of meat either served as a taco or burrito and always popular Mexican beverage, horchata, rice milk with cinnamon and sugar.  I ate a combo burrito of Carne Asada and Lengua(tongue). The meat was perfectly seasoned and cooked. The burrito is wrapped in foil and served with a squeeze bottle full of homemade green tomatillo salsa, which has a hint of spice. The horchata comes from a large freezer chest where it is ladled out of a large container into a styrofoam cup. The horchata is perfectly sweet with a hit of cinnamon and horchata slush covers the bottom of the cup.  Locals adorned the place and chattered over the music. We (my gringo friend and I)  drew stares as we walked in. After the initial culture shock, the staff was friendly and the regulars quick to make recommendations.  La Pasadita shows it's weathered facade inside and out, but after eating some authentic Mexican food from this joint, you will understand how eating in this hole in the wall only makes you feel cozy and comfortable as you uncomfortably try to finish the huge burrito. Walk-in with an open mind and walk out with a full stomach and a new gem to brag to your friends about. ¡Buen Provecho!
Great Carne Asada and super juicy barbacoa!  I recommend this to anyone looking for authentic Mexican tacos.  The flan is really good too.

I LOVE La Pasadita steak tacos so much I want to marry them! There are the La Pasaditas on the same block because they get so busy. My favorite is the one located on the south/west side of the street. The guacamole is amazing!
Average Mexican food.  Extra points for being open late. Not sure if the food actually tastes decent, but drunk me seems to think so.
Great skirt steak tacos.   Tips: - The bored firefighters spend a lot of their free time waiting to tow anybody who parks in their spots. - Ron Magers ordered steak tacos and took down 4.
Their barbacoa is to die for. Thankfully trill bitches don't die. We multiply.

Why are there three restaurants on Ashland Ave. all named La Pasadita? Is this a trick? Am I seeing in triplicate?  For the longest time, I thought this was one of those unexplainable Chicago mysteries but a little research on the La Pasadita website reveals that the restaurant on the east side of the street, La Chiquita (the small one), is the original location from 1976; the restaurant on the northwest restaurant is El Largo (the long one), which was the second location; and the southwest restaurant, El Nuevo (the new one), is the third location that was opened to focus more on customer service and "Americanized" Mexican food for the yuppies.  After reading this, I figured out that the restaurant I went to was El Largo, the long one, and I must say it was kind of a disappointment. I'm not looking for frills when it comes to my taco fix. I'm just looking for some damned good meat with a spicy kick and La Pasadita's food was really lacking some oomph! If this was supposed to be the authentic Mexican version of their tacos "seasoned with a secret mix that only family members are privy to", I would hate to taste the bland the yuppified Tex-Mex version of their food at El Nuevo.  I also ordered a chile relleno, because this white girl ain't afraid of some heat. It was good. I've had better though.  After hearing people rave about La Pasadita, I left feeling quite disappointed. I get better tacos from the taco cart outside of my train station.

I don't know what all the other yelpers are thinking.  Had a super burrito with chicken and beef on friday and finished chewing the steak on tuesday.  I hate to slam a respected establishment but this was pretty brutal.  Beware.

One of the best things about living in Chicago is the Mexican food options.  There are many great places BUT La Pasadita is NOT one of them.  About an hour ago, my co-worker and I carried out 2 ORDERS OF SUPER BURRITOS.  Disgusting!!!  Absolutely sickening.  I ordered half steak (carne asada) and half chicken.  Chicken was a dried out big chunks of flavorless white meat and the steak was tough as a leather.  No joke.  the whole burrito weighed about 2 - 2.5 lb but it was about 50% tortilla.  Who wants a mouthful of tortilla?  they made me wait 25 minutes for 2 burritos.  That's okay.  It is a small business and they were somewhat busy at 11:45 am.  As I cut the burrito in half, much of the filling spilled out.  You could not make out the ingredients due to glop of sour cream and guac.  The whole thing looked gross and tasted worse.  It was a bit steep at $8.00 but that's fine if the quality was there.  If anyone is thinking about going to La Pasadita, call me up and I will take a dump in a bag for $4.00  At least you will not be able to see the difference.  DO NOT GO THERE!!  DO NOT GET THE SUPER BURRITO!!
Get the carne asada tacos. That's all. I could eat them every single day.
Burritos as big as Bernie's head.  If you know Bernie you'll be impressed.   Complete dive but the food is tops.  While we're working we'll send someone over for take out and eat in the office.

Am I the only one that things it's odd that there are 3 of the same named restaurants on the same corner of our fair city? I get not wanting any competition (or maybe it's that they don't want their customers having to cross a big street?) but c'mon! When a friend says they are meeting you here in the wee hours of the morning- make sure you know which one they are talking about.  That aside- this is a burrito place. A giant, $7 burrito with little pieces of steak, cilantro and onions wrapped up in a warm tortilla. And that's it. Period. No mas. (unless you pay extra from a short list of condiments) Or pick a taco, $3.50 each, not as good of a deal as the burrito.  The burritos were huge but inconsistent. My friend had one and while his was dry, mine must have had all the pan drippings in it- for one bite later- I had juice of all sorts coming out of my burrito and making it one soggy mess to eat. You better like onions and cilantro for that is really the only flavor here!  The interior of the restaurant is nothing to write home about, and the bathrooms were disgusting (so much so my friend told me to not even go in there). The good news? Street parking is plentiful on this stretch of Ashland which makes it an easy late night choice.  Something tells me I wasn't drunk enough to eat at this place. And maybe my friend was- for he left a happy camper, and I left wondering why the heck I had stopped in.

This place is the best cheap Mexican food joint in the city. Their steak is better than any Mexican food joint in the City and better than most food joints in the City. I almost always get a steak torta or steak tacos. However, you have to ask for cheese on your tacos as this is not standard practice here. Great for lunch, dinner, or late night cravings.

Barbacoa burrito: too much meat. I can't believe I'm saying that.  It is the most mostest beef you will find anywhere, though.  I can't get enough of it. They don't have all the different kinds of meat you typically would ask for at such an establishment under one roof, like chicken.  With that and the 3 locations in the same half block, one has to question their business model.  Doesn't matter though, the barbacoa is all you need anyway.

Tasty and seasoned carne asada as always.  Simple and cheap.  Came here for a quick lunch and was satisfied as always.   The tacos only come with onion and cilantro so if you want extras such as cheese or sour cream, it'll cost ya...just be sure to pile on the black spicy sauce as you won't find it anywhere else.  And if you do, please fill me in. =)  Love that stuff.

This place's food is over rated.  BUT there is a reason I am still a fan... They are the absolute only place to go to if you are drunk in the area and want a bite to eat.  their late night tacos will satisfy and sort of cravings.  The price is right.  And they are super friendly to the post party drunks in the area as they are the number one client!

What. The. Hell.  In search of drunken, late-night food, I thought none better than La Pasadita, right?  WRONG.  A dry steak burrito with onions and cilantro doth not suffice, friends.  Things missing from La Pasadita's burrito:  -cheese (yes, you can ask for it...I suggest you do so, but um, why is this not standard? I'm pretty sure Mexican people eat cheese. -Sauces. Salsa might be a nice touch. Sour cream? Perhaps. Shit, I'd take hot sauce so I don't have to choke down a dry lump of steak tortilla.  -Guacamole? Or...I don't know, SOMETHING wet.  -Grease? Where is it!? None to be found.  It's a typical divey Mexican joint that lacks any semblance of flavor. None. Zero. And I even knew this fairly intoxicated. Plus, the girl was downright surly with me when I asked if they had a chicken burrito. SORRY, lady...I'm fairly certain most burrito places have chicken. I'm not asking for tofu or seitan, so cheer the hell up or serve chicken. The choice is yours.  Methinks the margins are fairly good for Mr. Pasadita at $7 a pop for these blah boys. Onions and cilantro are quite cheap.  I'll be going to Trespasada next time. Someone told me they have cheese and stuff. And maybe even more than one kind of meat. I'm not sure I care how strange it is that Pasadita has 3 of the same restaurant in one block. If they all are like this one, I'm out.

Being from southern California, I am VERY critical and particular about my beloved Mexican food. With that being said, I'd give this 4 stars for being good Mexican food in Chicago, but 3 stars overall in comparison to Mexican food I've had throughout my life. My cousin said the barbacoa tacos are a must, so I ordered one along with a carne asada taco to compare. Barbacoa was definitely more tasty (and tender) but let me just warn you--these tacos are GREASY! You can almost feel your arteries clogging. I do appreciate this place for satisfying my craving while I was away from Cali, but travel over to the [best] coast for more legit Mexican food!

Amazing Steak Tacos!  My boss lady said the chicken ones weren't as good as the steak so i would say Steak all the way!!!! These tacos are good anytime of day especially after you've been out painting the town red till the wee morning hours :)
Best place for carne asada tacos when you're drunk.  Period.

La Pasadita is one of the great authentic taquerias in the city of Chicago. The value is pretty exceptional, which is to say the prices are reasonable, and also that what you get in return is of fine quality.  The menu is as simple as it gets, which will no doubt turn off people used to shopping a tome-like menu to find their favorite dish. But what these people do, they do spectacularly, which is always superior to an extensive menu in my opinion.  You can have your tacos prepared with the traditional cilantro and onion accompaniment, or you can get lettuce and tomato if you're into that sort of thing.  The steak is charbroiled for excellent flavor and texture. The barbacoa is steamed and heaping with chunks of seasoned beef. Whatever you choose, it'll be worth the low price of admission in flavor and size. Everything on the menu is big, and lethal because they're all stuffed with generous portions of meat.  The staff is typical of the best Mexican spots anywhere: they're polite, lightning-fast, and perpetually busting their asses every shift (so don't be afraid to drop a buck or two in that tip jar).  There's a few stellar reasons why this place can sustain locations all over the city, but the Ashland branches are my favorite. There are three on this block, so...you really can't miss it. Nor should you.

I O.D.'ed on sleep today, I woke up at 8 pm and hungry as hell. No time to cook- La Pasadita it is! I thought I would try the "restaurant" this time thinking the menu will offer something different. Nope. Same ole burritos/tacos. I was starving so I finished off the chips and salsa right away. By the time my carne asada burrito got to me, I was kinda full already. The burrito was SALTY and took me two cans of Coke to make it half way.  This is the first time that I was not able to finish it. I'm ashamed and dehydrated.

I really just don't get it.  How is this place the king of Yelp mexican food? Perhaps in terms of value received, La Pasadita does pretty well.  After all, I got a barbacoa burrito that was filled literally 100% with meat.  I suppose in some way this makes it "a good deal". Unfortunately what I'm looking for in a burrito is not just meat but also a variety of other ingredients that provide a delicious array of different flavors and textures.  La Pasadita's burrito had none of these.  Instead of a mind-numbingly sleep inducing late night meal, when I got home I found myself working the dental floss hard to get all the meat out of my teeth. A rare instance of yelp leading me astray.

There is something you need to be prepared for when you enter one of the three unassuming little restaurants called La Pasadita on Ashland in Chicago.  After a visit here you're mind may change in ways that you cannot control. You will have started a downward spiraling sensory addiction that is very hard to recover from.  Eat the tacos my friend. And enjoy them. This is the best taco on planet earth. No joke.  Jay

I have been going here for years and I still love it dearly !!!  I go to the one farthest south on ashland, just in case you are wondering. STEAK is KING here !! really... what more can i say... grilled perfection. I can only speak for myself... I love the steak torta and steak tacos... and a couple cans of coke... the rice and beans are also very delicious... I will probably end up here in the next week or so... can't wait, like usual !!!

With three restaurants a block apart I am not 100% sure this is the one I went to.  You can't miss on their Tacos though.  These were the ebst Tacos I have ever had and I love Mexican food.  The best part is that these are simple.  LaPasadita has the most authentic tacos in Chicago.  I had the steak and chorizo and the other choice was tongue.  In addition to the meat, it came with onions and fresh cilantro with green salsa on the side. Definitely one of the best things I have ever eaten and among the best Mexican on any level in Chicago.  Not only was it good, I paid only $8.50 for four tacos.  I definitely plan on stopping in the next time I am in the area.

So, on the way home from another event with fellow yelper's, someone suggested La Pasadita as we were all hungry and in need of some noms. La Pasadita was a solid three. I don't think it was necessarily worth effort we expended to get here, but the food was decent. I scarfed down a beef burrito that was quite tasty and I regret not getting a horchata. Apparently there is a full sized restaurant "La Pasadita" across the street with a full menu, which I just don't understand. Why does this one exist and why didn't we go next door. Overall, it satisfied a need, and maybe I will try it again if I am in the area.

Totally decent chile relleno taco.  Of course, in my drunken state anything was going to seem decent but this tasted like I would have enjoyed it sober too.  But worth a mile walk to get to? Not so sure about that.  And the prices seemed a little steep for what we ate.   I'm sure I'd come back if I was in the neighborhood.  But would I make a destination of it? Probably not.

We walked about a mile go eat here because one of the people in our group said this place was great.  I thought the steak taco was perfectly tasty, but it wasn't worth the effort, or the money.  I went next door to get nachos, and I couldn't believe we hadn't gone there.  That place was an actual restaurant, and had all of the items we ordered from this place. I didn't think this place was worth the walk, but it was fine.

I luvvvv this place!! My mom got me into this place cuz she has been going here seen she was younger and I jus luvv their SOFT BEEF TACOS W/CHEESE, ONIONS AND CILANTRO..so GOOD! Everytime me and her goes shopping around here we HAVE to stop in and get LOTS AND LOTS OF TACOS BEFORE WE GO HOME CUZ WE DONT STAY TO CLOSE TO HERE LOL If you're looking for a GOOD MEXICAN RESTAURANT  to eat at THIS IS THE PLACE! LUVVVVV IT! ;)))) NOTE: IF UR GOING HERE DURING LUNCH HOURS GET IN EARLY CUZ IT CAN BE PACKED AT TIMES!

Last night, I had a revelation. And that was why have I not been walking here and eating this all the time? I don't live far away and it was AMAZING. I had a carne asada burrito, and I was asked if I wanted onions and cilantro. OF COURSE I DO. I added some sour cream and then decided that I wanted to try la lengua (tongue for those who don't speak espanol) taco. They were out of guac when I was there, which I was fine with. And I ordered some horchata, because why the hell not, it's a dollar. So I sat down with my food and my group, poured salsa verde all over my burrito, wrapped it back up and then decided that it was time to try the taco first. I bit in, semi scared but excited and wow. Burst of flavor in my mouth. I expected it to be super tough, but it was tender and had a good flavor, better than expected. I would definitely get it again, especially since I truly do believe in using as much of the animal as possible. The burrito was delicious as well! Tender steak, not at all gristly. I actually appreciated the simplicity of the burritos-this isn't Chipotle and this place isn't called "Mission Burrito." There doesn't need to be a ton of toppings for it to be good-and it was delicious. I will be back in the near future and I will probably be getting the same exact thing. And, the salsa verde on the table was a plus, as I LOVE the heat that it gave to my burrito. But also, hell, the horchata was so delicious that I got an extra one to take home with me. It also was very good in chasing away the heat while eating my burrito, if only for me to bite in again for more heat.  I hate describing things as such but YUMMY is all I can say.
Pros - i've been back after that a mishap -Love their chile rellenos.  -Small parking lot  Cons -the wait tends 2 b long -service is never the greatest, so don't expect it
Hands down the best Carne Asada burrito in Chicago.  Nothing comes close.  In the running for the best burrito in the US.

This place is great! It has 3 locations in the same block, they are not to different but one conforms to more a family style dinning and the other two are more of a quick drop in and pick up type of place. I loved the carne asada burrito i had and the my friends enjoyed the beef and tongue tacos they ordered. This place has a rep for excellence and they did not defy it

Three locations all on the same street, all of them are owned by the same person.  1 is a quickstop only doing steak taco's, burritos, and the like.  The one down the street from this is a sit down place with a larger menu.  Finally there is one across the street as well.  I haven't been to this one so I can't comment on it.  This "chain" is guess, has just about the best burrito's on the north side of Chicago.  The carne asada is amazing, and the steak is delicious.  Super burritos are more than I can handle in one sitting, stuffed with meat cheese avocado, rice everything you could want.  But that doesn't stop me from trying. The meats they have here are truely a stand out, it's flavorful and always well cooked.  My wife is from California and she always rags on the Mexican in Chicago.  This is one of the first places that got her seal of approval.

One word, Breaded Steak Dinner!!!  Crap, that's 3 words, but whatever, its 7AM, and I'm hungry.  This is a great place to go after a night of drinking and getting rejected by the ladies at the various venues in the area.  I can't wait to go back.

Best carne asada tacos in Chicago!  We even hunted for carne asada tacos in Mexico...La Pasadita is still better (and I'm talking hole in the wall joints in Mexico, not your tourist strip taco joints). It's true - these tacos are bare bones, meat, cilantro, onion, chihuahua cheese by request (a must!).  But with meat marinated like this who needs the extra filler of veggies and rice?!? And I must say the orchata is one of my favorites, but somehow they always seem to run out before I get there at 4am.  =(

Mexican food is always a good idea after a long evening at the bar.  Well - it's what I have always heard. Actually before last Saturday I had never really experienced the tortilla as universal hangover remedy. Lame, I know. But just FYI we froggies (wonderful nickname given by our lovely British neighbors) don't eat Mexican food after a long night but........onion soup. Yup. At least back in the days. I am getting old. So.........I hadn't eaten since brunch and was really in the mood for a great burrito. I left my drinking companion order at the counter and sat down in the sad little booth. Floors are dirty, everyone has blurry eyes, I just want to eat and get out. Turns out - my burrito is only filled with meat. Well, and onions and cilantro. But no rice, no beans, no salad, no corn or whatever else you can find in an American burrito. I am not at Chipotle. Damn..... It was still good but had I known, I would have just got regular tacos and called it a night.

The multiple locations on one block situation is  confusing especially since some dont offer certain things like tomatoes or what not.  Their food is very tasty and super cheap.  I am mexican so I can say with  confidence that its pretty authentic (the rice and beans are good but not so authentic). The 10 dollar burrito can feed like 4 people and the meat is great.  I love it.

Tacos and burritos, cash only (credit cards at the location across the street).  Nice and simple, really delicious, tons of meat packed into a corn tortilla.  I won't try anything else but the tacos, not even the burritos.  No matter how late/early in the day, theyre always consistent.

This place is legit, the real deal, rock solid.  I stumbled upon it one drunken night soon after moving to Chicago, and it remains my favorite Mexican food in Chicago to this day.  That's saying a lot because believe it or not, Chicago has top notch Mexican food.  First off, La Pasadita is cheap, very cheap.  A taco and tostada will feed you all day and it'll set you back $4.  The chips and salsa are free, and are divine.  Their specialty is their steak, and it is awesome.  It's greasy, it's juicy, it's tasty.  They don't skimp on anything here, and everything is fresh and wonderful.  I will visit you again La Pasadita.

This place has like 14 locations within a block, so no clue which one I should post about... but they are all awesome. By far one of my favorite tacos in the city... nothing better than drunken carne asada tacos from La Pasadita.  Tried the Chile Relleno's last night and yum yum in my tummy.

Went here alone on a saturday night. The place was packed. I had to wait for a table because the people getting take out thought it would be cool to take up several tables near the register while they waited. Finally able to order and was given a small basket of chips with 3 salsas. Two of them were ok, but not great. The chips were pretty good. I ordered 3 tacos. A barbacoa, carne asada, and chorizo. Went authentic with the barbacoa (cilantro + onions) and american style with the other two (cheese + lettuce). By far the carne asada was the best. The barbacoa was bland and fatty. The chorizo was ok, it had a good flavor, but it was kind of suspect, so I'm glad I only ate one.  I've read a ton of good reviews about this place and gotten recommendations for it. Honestly I was disappointed, it seemed like a run of the mill taqueria, nothing fancy not even very good.   I also waited for 10 minutes to pay because there was only one person working the register. Oh and the bathrooms were pretty nasty too and out of TP.  Not being a local, I'm not familiar with what else is around so maybe this place is the best, but I'll be hitting someplace else when I'm back in town.

The best taqueria I've been to in Chicago!  Yes I'm Asian, but my Latino friends agree.  Therefore it must be truth :)  What should you order?  Tacos of course!  Awesome barbacoa (steamed beef).  If you're adventurous, have some of the delicious lengua (beef tongue).  If you're a little conservative, do the carne asada.  Of course, go with the true Mexican style of onions and cilantro toppings.  They make good horchata too. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  My biggest dilemma there is how many tacos to order.  2?  5?  Haha.  It tastes great when you're completely drunk (and it may help you out in the morning), but it's also great tasting when sober.  It's almost always a stop if I'm going out in Wicker Park or Bucktown.  It says a lot when Mexicans say they miss home when eating at this place.   Oh yeah, I usually go to the smaller Las Pasadita.  They serve pretty much tacos (and burritos for gringos hehe).  if you go to the big La Pasadita, you can sit down and get more dishes like Arrachera.  These other dishes are fine, but you can probably get better at truly sit-down restaurants like in Pilsen.  I'm very happy just having tacos at La Pasadita.

CHICKEN BURRITO! CHICKEN BURRITO! CHICKEN BURRITO!  Legend has it, say that three times in front of a mirror in a dark room, and when you turn on the light you'll want to go to La Pasadita.  I've tried it, it's true.  The best chicken burrito in Chicago, it goes well with the best horchata in Chicago too.  I'm hungry right now for one.  Time to turn off the lights.  Go there!
Best salsa negra ever!  Burritos, tacos, chips, platters all great.  Been going here since the late 80's and love it!

By far the best tacos in Chicago. Carne Asada with cilantro and onion along with a heap of salsa verde, you'll be in heaven.  Wash it down with an Orchata or Sidral, it's a great meal any time of day!

Hm. I'm torn. I've had good at La Pasadita, but this last time left a poor taste in my mouth.  1. The girls at the register do not speak or understand English. This makes ordering a wee bit difficult. 2. Pricey - two burritos and chips $20! 3. I thought I saw one of the cooks literally throw a burrito to another cook to wrap it up...oddly, it wasn't the throwing of the burrito that bothered me, it was the fact that both of them weren't wearing gloves. Surely I was seeing things, but alas 4. The girls putting chips in the baskets and packaging them up - no gloves. And no sign of anyone having washed their hands before digging into the chips or passing around burritos and tacos to be wrapped up. 5. The chips, while freshly fried, have been completely burnt the last couple of times I've been there. Never mind there's not a grain of salt on them. I guess there's a reason that people are usually plastered when they want to get a burrito.

Solid, humble, cheap Mexican food in Chicago.  I recall dropping in here with a friend in the midst of an exhausting furniture shopping nearby.  We scarfed down a few yummy tacos within minutes of receiving them.  The barbacoa was so friggen good, I had to place another order.  If in the area, stop by.  You won't regret it (though your arteries might).

Skip the carne asada (steak) and go right for the barbacoa (steamed beef) tacos! The meat is melt-in-your mouth tender and the great flavor is complemented by the soft corn tortillas, fresh onions/cilantro, and solid salsa.  It's weird that they have 3 locations at the same intersection, but this place is perfect after a night of drinking in Bucktown/Wicker Park and ranks up there with my other favorite, Arturros.  Affordable too: $2 for the carne asada, $1.85 for the barbacoa. See you there!
This place is pretty amazing, great for late night munchies. But be careful which door you go in, I think there are 3 including one across the street. Each one serves different meats.

Ode to the Steak Burrito.   Oh Steak Burrito, how I love thee so.   How I long for your flavor and zest  Your Yumminess and spice is better than the rest  I love your sauces, including the green and the red  The Burritos Girth is as big as my head  It has been too long since I witnessed your delight  I will be dreaming of Mole Sauce all through the night  When people deny your greatness, I think they are a fool  The thought of a La Pasadita Burrito makes me want to drool  With the weekend nearly upon us, I long for my first bite  La Pasadita Burrito, you are a dreamy delight.

Did La Pasadita just get lazy and slap down their Taste of Chicago booth on Ashland Avenue with this one? I mean, seriously, it's all there.  The limited menu, the seemingly makeshift grill you can see from the front, the less than stellar counter staff.  The only thing missing were the 12 tickets for $8. I think I made a mistake going to this La Pasadita.  There are just too many choices when you've got three restaurants from the same ownership group - WITH THE SAME NAME - on the same corner so I was bound to screw it up! You've got La Pasadita I (my numbers, not theirs for the record) next door which is a fully stocked sit down restaurant.  La Pasadita II, a cosy little taco shack, sits across the street.  Then you've got this one - "the trey" - the runt of the litter.  This LP (I verified the address to be sure) is a simple taqueria serving only five kinds of tacos and five kinds of burritos for the late night drunken munchers of Ukrainian Village. There is nothing wrong, of course, with simplicity.  I love a good quick serve taco cart (that's what she said).  The problem with "trey" (we're on a nickname basis) is that the burritos and tacos on the menu are not the simple sort you can just roll up and slap on the grill.  I waited quite a while for my chile relleno tacos (I can only imagine how long the wait would have seemed if I had gone drunk instead of sober) as the line in the restaurant started to grow. Had it been worth the wait, I would give the restaurant the benefit of the doubt.  But the two tacos I got - besides the dry breaded chilis - had cilantro and onions but nothing that would actually add to the flavor or consistency of the total package.  Plus they were pricey little buggers at $3.50 a pop!  Not bad, but not $3.50 times two good! I sat in the booth below a sign that said these were named the best taco in Chicago by Check, Please.  This must have been won by another location (obviously with the same name) because these were not close. Is it better than Flash Taco one blue line stop further as a quick stop?  Yes.  But that's not saying much.  What isn't?  It was good enough to make me wonder about the other two La Pasaditas, but I will not be rushing back to this Taste of Chicago version!  There are two seemingly better choices (with the same name) right there, after all!
LOVIN LOVIN LOVIN this place...... Tacos are terrific the Fajitas are EXCELLENT.. the chips and salsa is the bomb.  Prices???  a bit pricey but I love this restaurant for the authentic taste.
I love this place.  The steak burritos are the best.  I crave them.  You can smell the steak from a block away.  The super burritos are big enough for two meals.

GREASE, GREASE,GREASE ! My girlfriend and I ordered 2 steak burritos and 2 sodas at $17.00. I felt it was pricey, since I have been coming here on and off since 1997. The last time was in 2008. Anyway, when we bit in the burritos a stream of grease poured out. Yuk! It wasjust so greasy,it overwhelmed the taste of the meat.The cilantro and the onions tasted like they were soaked for hours in fat.  What place charges you extra for tomatoes in your burrito?This is proof of another place that has gotten greedy and lazy and lost it's touch that got it known. I will not go back!
Late nite munchies after clubbin' or just drinkin' with pals?? Come here!! Mmm steak tacos and fast service, its a DIVE yes... but great tacos!! : ) Thank you La Pasadita!!

I walked home and as soon as I walked in the door I undressed the burrito and took a bite. I was surprised at how good it was. It came with cilantro, cheese and onions along with some green sauce. I kept biting and every bite was better than the last.  It was great just needs a clean up

Don't really understand why they have three locations around this intersection, but this is the northern of the two western locations.  This looks to be the tacqueria.  Got two huge burritos.  Carne asada and barbacoa.  Steak and shredded beef with fresh cilantro and white onions.  A little salsa verde to jack it up and you're all set.  These were fantastic.  The barbacoa was a bit overseasoned for me (paprika?).  I preferred the carne asada.  Again these were both two huge burritos.  And yes, for those of you following along, I ate both of them.  This little piggy would not recommend that you do the same.   This place is great.  Now, can someone explain to me why there are three locations right here?

HOTDAMN!!!!! I may have just ate the greatest steak burrito of all time! I was starving as I got off of work and I kept thinking where should I go to grab a quick bite when I get off of the train? I thought about Wendys, but did not feel like dealing with their crazy ass 5 O clock line. I looked over and there it was calling me, La Pasadita! I walked in and wanted a chicken burrito and they laughed at me saying I will have to go to the next door location to get chicken. I did not feel like doing that so I went with the steak! I walked home and as soon as I walked in the door I undressed the burrito and took a bite. I was surprised at how good it was. It came with cilantro, cheese and onions along with some green sauce. I kept biting and every bite was better than the last. I lay here right now smelling my fingers, remembering the delicious burrito I just devoured. It set be back around $7.50 and was well worth it!

Ok. There are three of these. I have only been to the two on the west side of the street- the one closest to division, which is just tacos and burritos, and the one slightly further south, that has a full menu and table service. No matter which one I go to, I always get asada tacos. They're the best I've had in Chicago. Their salsas are both great- I especially like the salsa negra. Another can't miss is the quesadillas nortenos. 4 half moons of cheese-filled fried tortillas in a delicious mild homemade tomato sauce, with sauteed onions and little clumps of goat cheese. Pasadita is the real deal. Burritos are legendary, but I have yet to attempt.

Carne asada tacos and burritos are the main attraction here. The tender, flame-broiled meat is always consistent and the garnish of cilantro and onions (white, raw) are a perfect complement to grill-charred meat. My personal favorite are the small, brown bits that pack massive flavor and complement the bigger, more tender chunks of marinated steak. The prices have gone up slightly in the past year, but that's OK. Once you smell the meat cooking, you're going to pay what you have to pay to get it.  Don't forget the horchata, it's the best around and most authentic according to my Amigos Mexicanos. The salsa verde is pleasantly vinegar based, thin and hot (somewhere between hot and very hot). All in all a great taco experience and probably the best steak taco in the Midwest.
This place has an amazing taco but it may be going downhill. The past few times I've been here the steak was really fatty. The negro sauce rules!

I remember when I worked at Whole Foods and just about the only time the guys could convince me to go get lunch was if someone brought up La Pasadita (and paying for it sweetened the deal!). Everyone I know has their preference (and I don't know anyone who really likes the one across the street).......but I love this place.  The one next door is equally as good (and super fast) but, they don't serve chicken tacos and I'm one of those people that needs 2 chicken and 1 steak.  This is one of the few places I'll order a burrito at.  I'll usually have them add rice and not put in beans, and the layer of guacamole is the perfect finishing touch!  I know places will add avocado, but, there's just something about this place where I won't add avocado in any other burrito.   The burritos are massive.  My mom laughed when she saw a man apparently order the largest one they have and his face was just "what is this??"  Needless to say, he took some home.   The salsa here definitely gives me a run for my money.  Maybe it's because I'm so used to drenching things in hot sauce and salsa and forget that theirs is actually kind of hot enough that I don't NEED to drench my food in it, but that's usually after the fact.   The owner is so nice as well.  His sister (I believe it's his sister) owns La Palapita on Milwaukee (just south of Montrose, I believe) which made complete sense when I found out because they're just as delicious.   I've never ordered their plates of food, but I see people share them frequently when I go there and they look good and there's SO MUCH.  Prices are fair and they're fast.  As much as I hate the neighborhood (ok, I just hate the Milwaukee/Ashland/Division intersections because I have no patience)...........if someone mentions getting food from here I'm willing to suck it up and go there. My mother LOVES the chile relleno tacos while I keep it simple.  Traditional tacos with cilantro and onion in 2 thin corn tortillas.

i miss la pasadita.  pretty much every restaurant i used to go to in chicago (RIP soul by the pound) is gone, but the three la pasadita locations right there on ashland remain.  steadfast.   i started going to la pasadita in the late 80's when, of all things, a vegetarian turned me on to the place.  a mutual friend of ours took her, and she had a chile relleno.  she said that she was tempted to eat meat when she saw the burrito.  no wonder.  the la pasadita burrito is a homage to grilled carne asada.  unlike the garbage can burritos you see at some joints, the la pasadita burrito is a mouth watering meaty delight.   excuse me.  i had to wipe the drool off my laptop.   la pasadita has a very small menu.  if i'm not mistaken, carne asada, and chile relleno.  your choices of what you can get on your carne asada (which they grill and chop right there in front of you) is onion, cheese, cilantro, and salsa verde.  that's it.   so let me recap.  no beans, rice, tomato products.  no million other types of burritos, tacos.  they may have a couple others, but i wouldn't know because in 20 years i only got the carne asada.  jesus, why would i get anything else?  the burrito may not look huge, but i guarantee it will fill you up.  it is not "greasy", that's juice.  delicious juice. . .  excuse me while i drool again.

While the carne asada are some of the better steak tacos i've had, the barbacoa was even better. Perfectly tender and tasted almost like some really good brisket. The verde salsa was not too spicy but a nice complement to the generous helpings of cilantro and onions...

UPDATE: deducting 1 star for recently lackluster service and inconsistency. i now recommend las asadas as my fav taco place. best steak taco. this is the northwestern-most location of the three on the corner of ashland / division and the only one i currently frequent.  after a recent experiment with their steamed beef taco, i have returned to always ordering the same thing here: 3 carne asada tacos (yes cilantro + onions) 1 small horchata don't forget to grab a bottle of salsa verde and apply generously.

This is the place to get better than average taqueria. While you can pretty much get what you expect from any of the thousands of taquerias in the city this place definitely stands head and shoulders above the rest. The only question you will have is which place to go into. They have 3 different storefronts with the same name all next to across the street from each other!  While you can order "fancier" plates when going here, I stick to my cravings and always go with regular el pastor tacos and/or burritos. WARNING: Never order the super burrito. It is a physical abomination. While it is good, you will be thoroughly shocked/amazed/embarrassed by the magnitude of this monstrosity. Stick with the regular size burrito.  The steamed beef is also excellent here and nothing seems greasy or cheap like other taquerias. Simply, La Pasadita is a winner and my gf and I have often made trips to frequent this establishment come rain or shine.

I love this hole-in-the wall (well actually, 3 holes in 2 walls).   This is one spot that when I take a bite out of the carne asada taco with cheese, cilantro and onions, I close my eyes and imagine I'm in Mexico.  It's sad when I open my eyes again...but at least I still have another taco to eat.  YUM!  Super flavorfilled meat...greasy but that's part of the charm ;)

Well.. there are three of these on a small half-block radius.. Not sure if people have their favorites, but I really like this one. Had their ribeye taco and two llengua tacos.. Soo good. Really liked their salsas they seem to make fresh..  Nothing bad to say about this place at all.. just waiting for a time to go with a group for their big meat platter!!

Carne asada tacos are the best I've had in Chicago. Chicken Quesadilla was phenomenal. They offer two salsa verdes, One roasted and one fresh. mmm....mmmm..mmmm.... Strange business plan, though, to have all three restaurants within a block of each other. Am I missing something?

DISCLAIMER: I'm from the Colinas Enchiladas suburb of Burritoville, California (Taco County) and since I lived closer to Mexico I know better than you. Seriously?  Don't listen to anyone who starts their review with "well I'm from California" because they don't know what is delicious any better than you do. Just because Mexican food is different in California doesn't mean it's better. And it's really not different, but thanks for telling us all where you're from and why that makes you special.  La Pasadita's horchata is as good as any you'll drink anywhere. You can read about a lot of their other gems in all these other reviews (and maybe you should start with the steak tacos) but one hazy evening I decided on the barbacoa platillo and I haven't ordered anything else since.

DUDE... whether it's late night after the bars, after work, lunch, ANYTIME is a good time to eat here.  I prefer the steak tacos, they are great. No chewy meat and all fresh ingredients. I have eaten at all 3 of the restaurants on the strip and had good experiences at each of them. If you haven't tried please do.. well worth the wait and drive.

La Pasadita has one of the worst burritos in the city. It tastes like an unclean grill and is simply not put together well. It is big in size, but I didn't want to finish it because it was not good. There are many options for mexican food in this area, so there is no reason to go here.  The staff, however, is friendly and they are open late.

My favorite burrito in Chicago.  When I was a kid, my dad would always go to the one across the street (the 'dirty' one).  There are like 18 La Pasaditas on the one block, and any one of them are awesome.  This one is my favorite (I think...I'm not sure if I got the right one!).

Hmf. After just having moved to Chicago from California, La Pasadita was extremely disappointing Mexican food.  Where's the black beans?  How about nice pico de gallo?  A little cilantro, por fa'?  Nope.  Only saving grace was the yummy horchata.  Hope I can find something a little better or I'll just have to move myself back to Cali! ;)
Carne asada tacos.  Steak, cilantro, onions.  So simple, yet so perfect...

After way to many trips to Taco Burrito King, this is what I've been looking for all along.  I had the ribeye burrito (super burrito, excuse me).  Extremely delicious & absurdly large.  Now, I've been known to consume large burritos in the past, but I couldn't stop eating the chacos (nachos).  The carne asada topping the chips had a real grilled taste, not just the painted on taco bell style grill marks.  I'm looking forward to several more trips for more menu items, but I'd be hard pressed to order anything from this place without also getting the chacos.  And to think I was yearning for the West Loop to get our own Chipotle.

This is the one with the really good horchata, and al pastor.  I hardly ever go to this one, because their al pastor isn't the best in the known universe, while the carne asada and to some degree the barbacoa of the adjacent Pasaditas are superior. The chicken at this one is not bad either.

Ah, the old standby. Doesn't matter which one you go to, all of them serve the most excellent steak burrito. To be honest, the five stars are all based on this aforementioned steak burrito. I don't really remember why (drunk) or when (in the last two years?) but once I tried a different burrito. I am sure it was good, but I would venture to say the chicken or tongue is the same as other places. In summation, if for some reason you haven't been here and love charred meat, cilantro & onions then go. please.

What can be said that hasn't already?  Came to this authentic restaurant for some good, true, Mexican food.  Had the complimentary chips and salsa and chicken tacos.  The chicken was beautiful (white meat, tender) and the guacamole on the tacos (special request) was delicious.  The black salsa was delicious, I even took some home with me!  Will definitely be back soon!

I'm from San Diego where every other restaurant has some form of mexican food, so I've had a hard time in Chicago finding Mexican food that is authentic and tasty, AND has some sort of vegetarian options. La Pasadita is all this, and more, although not nearly as good as some places back home. I tried to figure out which of the three locations is the one I go to, but I just couldn't figure out if this is the right one. But it's all the same, really. I recommend this for anyone looking for a tasty burrito for lunch, or a late night meal, seeing how they are open nice and late. I've only ever had the chips/salsa that they bring you, and the Veggie Burrito. I'm not a big fan of the salsas that they bring in the bottles, but my friends seem into it. I guess I'm more of a pico de gallo fan. The veggie burrito is good, and always more than enough food.  An extra MMMmmm for the horchata. :)

I dont know what you guys see in this place, but definately not worth the 5...or 4...or 3 stars even.  I went here right around 5pm....let me start off by saying "how can you eat at a place that has such a dump look!"The floors are all nasty with gum marks all over the place.  The service was horrible...I had to go get the menu myself, the wait staff was super slow and were just yapping instead of tending to the clients.  The salsa in the squeeze bottles was not even worth all the hoopla everyone keeps talking about.  They are right out of the bottle or something...and who the hell eats off of the squeeze bottles?  are you supposed to just squeeze all that junk on the stale nachos?  What about a bowl?  Last time i checked...salsa came in bowls...not squeeze bottles. The vegetarian burrito was burnt and down right nasty.  I also had ordered tacos, and NO...THEY ARE NOT THE BEST IN CHICAGO...and I have been to mexico, I have know what a TACO is....this taco had more sour cream than anything else. My wife hate the food as well.  Never again...I know why they have 3 locations...because the first two SUCK....and the third one probably sucks also. Thats my review of La PASADITA...waste of time. p.s. and when i asked for a knife...the waitress brought me back a spoon...a plastic one.  what a joke

Go for the STEAK TACOS!  The skirt steak is grilled, chopped, and served with onions and cilantro and a side of green tomatillo salsa.  Very simple, but the steak is so flavorful that you don't need anything else.  I'm also a fan of their chile relleno tacos, for those days when I'm not in the mood for steak.  I tried their tongue tacos, which were good, but I've had better.  Overall, though, I recommend it because the steak tacos rock.  We usually take our food to-go.

Ehhhh. I went here tonight after having several people swear up and down that La Pasadita's rocks the best tacos in all of Chicago. As a girl from L.A., I admittedly have a tendency toward some snobbery when it comes to my Mexican food. We have some amazing latin influence in Southern Cali and the abundance of authentic tacos is the shizznit.   I always grade on a sliding scale since I realize it might be difficult to translate that kind of Chicano greatness all the way in the middle of North America. Granted, La Pasadita still pales in comparison to what terrific taco promised land should be. The chips were stale and desperately aching for a salt bath, the two salsas offered (green and black) came in squeeze bottles and were pretty far from impressive. My super tacos were good but not much of a departure from a late night Burrito House mess deconstructed on lukewarm corn tortillas. I opted out of trying the torta... my bf did though, it's one of those Mexican sandwiches that looks like a taco on a kaiser roll. He said it was tasty-ish but to this Cali chick a sandwich bun just ain't legit in a taco joint.   I'm bummed out I didn't find my taco utopia here, although I'd go back if I needed a desperate refried bean fix. I'm almost afraid of the backlash of this review since La Pasadita seems to have you Yelparoos wrapped around its little churro, but I'm still pretty convinced to get a real Mexican experience I gotta head west...way west... like back to Cali west.

After a friend offered me one of her vegetarian tacos from La Pasadita, I knew I had found the Pringles of tacos, where one just isn't enough. The three locations of La Pasadita are confusing.   At this moment, I'm not even sure if I am reviewing the right restaurant. I drove down Ashland, hungry, and immediately noticed a car pulling out from a parking space right in front of (one) of the restaurants. "I gotta go!" I told my friend on my cell phone.   "I just scored a parking space right in front of La Pasadita!!" She's from North Carolina, so she wouldn't understand their rice, beans, and irritating lack of parking. I have driven past it several times, wanting to go in, but where would I park?  Oh, that's right.   Nowhere. I walked inside the yellow awning and noticed the menu had four items, all containing some animal byproduct. "Is this the location that serves vegetarian tacos?" I asked the waitress. "NO, you gotta go next door!" Off I went.   I waited in line behind a postal employee, still in uniform, who was yelling at the waitress to "make sure they put enough meat on my food!  Last time there was hardly any meat!!" I ordered my crazy cheap "Vegetariano!" tacos to go and am now saddened. They are so good, and I'll probably never score such a sweet parking space again.

If La Pasadita was a cute hipster girl with glasses and a penchant for sappy indie-rock, I would marry it in a heartbeat. The tortas are spectacular and at under four bucks, you can't really go wrong. Friday and Saturday nights are a little crowded with drunken bargoers, but it's worth fighting the crowds to eat there. Some of the best Mexican food I've ever had in my life....and I live with a real live Mexican! So you know that I know what I'm talking about.

I want to give this place a bad review; unfortunately, the food is really great. Of course, I grew up on the East Coast and spent a lot of time in New England, so walking into a Mexican joint and ordering a great taco is something I've never experienced before visiting Chicago/California.   My best bad Mexican food story - we were driving through the snow in backwoods New Hampshire one beautiful January night.  We pass by a diner/hair salon, and the sign claimed to have Mexican food.  We had to try it!   So this guy named Rich opened the door; the restaurant and men's barber shop were separated by a glass window.  In the shop there was a red hound barking loudly but without much fervor; it stopped barking when I stared at it.  Rich was apparently the sole proprietor there - he took your order, he cooked and served the food, and he shaved your beard and cut your hair.   He was really friendly, too - a lot of people in New Hampshire hate New Yorkers, who stand out like a sore thumb, but he asked us all these questions and was really interested in getting to know us. Of course, nothing on the menu was Mexican - broiled fish, T bone steak, baked chicken breast, etc.  Confusing.  But there was one Mexican dish: guacamole.  $9, the same price as the most expensive item on the menu.  But the best part was that the menu said there would be a table side presentation.  We asked Rich about it, and he showed us this huge stone bowl.  So we ordered it. A few minutes later, he came out with a plate of tortilla chips.  Then he grabbed the bowl, and as we watched, poured in some avocado flavored green powder and sour cream, and then served it to us on our side plates. Fan fucking tastic.  The fish was pretty good though. Back to La Pasadita, though.  The people here are annoying as hell, but the food is soooo good.  I've had problems both times I've come here with the service.  The first time, I ordered two chicken tacos, which are $1.55 each, and a side of sour cream, which the menu said was 50 cents.  The tacos were great, and they gave me a huge side of sour cream.  When I went to pay, I was told the sour cream was 3.50.  I pointed to the menu, where it said 50 cents, but they told me it was 50 cents for the small side and they had given me a large side.  I told them I didn't ask for a large side, but they told me that since I ate out of it, I had to pay the 3.50.  Kind of stupid since my two tacos cost 3.10. I promised myself I wouldn't go back, but I did today.  I made sure I asked for a small side of sour cream.  Twice.  The food was great, but the claimed to have no sauce that was spicier than the green and black sauce that was on the table.  I know this is not true, since they gave me a special spicy salsa verde the first time I went.  That annoyed me.  I also noticed that everyone in the restaurant got their food on a plate and were given a fork and knife.  I was given none of those; they were wrapped up like they were to go and brought to my table.  They knew it wasn't to go, though.  I asked for a plate, fork, and knife, and only got a plate and a fork. But the stuffed chilis are sooo good.  The tacos have tons of cilantro, and you get a whole bowl of tomatos and chips with everything you order.  I can probably find good food elswhere, but it's hard when you know there's a place that always has it.  Unfortunately, I'll probably be back.
this place is behind my boys house. we eat here all the time. steak burrito mmmmmm. tacos..mmmmm. love it.

I write this both because La Pasadita is a landmark institution to me, and because I read Ellie's review talking about poor service. I have always gotten great service here, with a smile, with speed, with courtesy. And the food is great. Not as exciting an experience to me as the smaller neighboring Pasaditas, but a near Northwest side landmark nonetheless.

yummers to the max!!! an added plus, this location has lettuce!!!!  the torta is amazing........w/ guacamole was the PERFECT touch.   take away 1/2 star for disregarding my tortilla de harina request; take away another 1/2 star for jipping me out of a taco! I will be back!!!  que delicioso....
I was sober. I loved it. Kick ass tacos and burritos.  (This is the larger, sit down one - right?)

La Pasadita is spanish for "dump," right? Holy crap, is this place a hole.  Yes, the tacos are good. Very good, in fact. If you go in the evening you'll see families chowing down, which is pretty cool. But these people who give it 4 or 5 stars must not count ambiance and cleanliness at all. Get your food to go, or get so drunk that you don't notice the surroundings. Note that I have no idea which of the 3 locations I'm adding this review to. I assume the food is good at all, but something tells me the others can't be too much better on the atmosphere scale.
Good tacos. Great place to pig out when you are hammered. Get the Torta   Al Pastor (pork).. it's really good. Mexican grease Pit for the late after party hunger.
Great steak tacos and burritos.  Not the nicest inside.  Good salsa too.

Of all the taco joints that I have been to in the city of Chicago, I'd have to say that La Pasadita has got to be one of the best!  In going here you should not be expecting the ambiance of service that you would get at a Lalo's but just great food at a cheap price.  The menu is quite authentic and if it is authenticity that you are after you have to try the lengua tacos!  I was a little skeptical of trying them at first but they have quickly become one of my favorites there.  What is lengua you might ask?  Its tongue.  Its not the same type that your mom used to cover in gravy and pass as something else!  If you are in this area,  you have to make a stop to one of the three La Pasadita's that are within a stone's throw to each other.  I also don't know why there are three so close to each other.  If anyone of you know, please let me know.

If you've been to this part of town, you may ask, "why are there 3 La Pasadita restaurants located a stone's throw away from eachother?" Well, even if you decide to indulge in one of these authentic restaurants, the question will remain unanswered.  no, seriously, that exact question is painted on the wall of this joint, but nowhere... and i mean NOWHERE is there an explanation.  the good news.. the food is so good that I can still sleep at night not knowing the answer. I highly recommend the combo fajita... muy sabrosa! the salsa's appearance is a tad creepy (think swamp water), but once again... apparently you don't ask questions in this part of town and just accept the fact that it is tasty as well.  comida para los gente.  just remember, don't ask questions or get too personal, you may be disappointed. (oh and they take credit cards.. the minimum is a ten spot)
The best (and faraway at that) steak burrito I've ever eaten in my life. (PS - I weigh about 220)

If I ever get shot, killed, stabbed, or hurt I am running to La Pasadita (or Lucia's deli).  Why?  Because the chances of finding Chicago cops eating in these locations are very strong.  Cops and I tend to have similar culinary attitudes (not necessarily attitudes about other things)... namely we like places that are sit down (why get back to work quickly), cheap, and give you lots of food.  The La Pasadita location with the wait service certainly fits that mold.  They give you chips and salsa and my experience with the service has been quick.  I must admit I am not feeling the tacos (a little too much cilantro for my tastes), but I love the tortas and the steak burritos.  Can get overwhelmingly busy, but the servers do their best.  Good stuff.

Ok, went to this taco shanty following a long night of drinking and a concert at Green Dolphin Street to feed my drunken hunger pangs.  Personally, I love the "dive" atmosphere and the wide spectrum of people who come in for the late night feeding frenzy. The horchata (rice milk) was to DIE for! And, I cannot tell you how happy my belly was with the steak fajitas. Of course, we all had some alcohol surging through our veins and we were all probably talking shit more than concentrating on the tasty food, but the steak was damn delicious. Watch out for the salsa because even if you think your tongue is made of steel, this salsa will make you exclaim in pain, "HIJOPUTA!"

THE PLACE FOR TACOS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Greatest place to eat tacos in Chicago. I have been going here since I was 5 years old...and then it was great. No matter what kind you want...they are great. Better when you are drunk but I've had them sober and still love them. Definitely not gonna be on Check Please or 190 N, so no service at all. But whatever by the time you get these tacos you will be a lil' on the tipsy side!

There are so many tacoes places in the city that claim to have the "Best Taco" in town that, well None of them do. They cancel each other out, and the flavors and the things that make them unique, all run together. La Pasadita is only extremly good if you are A. Drunk or B. Poor . I've gotten "bad" meat ( meat with a shit load of fat on it) very frequently and its made me develope a habit of having to go through all the meat in the taco, burrito, etc to take out the fatty meats. I wouldnt "drive from rogers park" for it....The service sucks if you look like you arent gonna tip or aren't hispanic!

So, everyone and their mother told me La Pasadita had the best tacos and burritos in Chicago.  I have to disagree. I thought the meat was tough, the cilantor and onion did not seem fresh.  To add insult to injury, while inside for 7 minutes...the local tow racket managed to get me for $150.  Bad neighborhood, bad tacos, bad restaurant.
Absolutely mouth watering.  The food is great! If you want authentic Mexican food, La Pasadita is the place to go!

The sit down restaurant (La Pasadita #269,185 all located on Ashland) is kind of like Mexican Ed Debevic's.  How, you may be asking? Well, if you would like horrible service and nasty attitude and would like to pay for it, then this is the place! Despite the service (or lack thereof) from the cranky cholas, the food still rocks.  The salsa on the tables will clear your sinuses for the next six months and the greasy but oh-so delicious tortas will absorb all the booze in your poor little tummy.  Or cure your munchies. Warning:  DO NOT TRY TO LEAVE A TIP ON THE CREDIT CARD.  One of the rude girls working snapped at me because I wanted to leave our tip on credit card and we had all of two bucks in cash.  Apparently, tipping on the cc is not allowed!  I know, I know people who only carry credit cards are annoying.  But let's be fair: I was an unemployed college student.  Capital One was my sugar daddy! If you're up north, go to Garcia's - they're way nicer, it's not as greasy and the rice and beans can't be beat.

Sorry, but I must strongly disagree with all those folks that think this place has the best (steak) tacos & burritos. Found the steak meat to be tough/chewey and not particularly tasty or well-seasoned. Tacos were also very greasy, and too little 'filling' of onions and cilantro. Also, we paid the extra 50cents for gaucamole, and there was barely a quarter-teaspoon if that on any of the Tacos. And, dissappointed there was no option to add real Avocado (which is my preference). The usual free Tortilla Chips were also not very well-made or tasty, and the 3 sauces to go with only so-so. The only positive note I'd make is that it is BYOB, so you can definately eat (& drink) on the cheap. But, for my money (and tastebuds), TACALITLAN beats this place hands down. (See my review of Tacalitlan).
Oh my how could I forget about this place!! I come here at least once a month to get my tacos de lengua and chile rellenos ...so cheesy and yummy!!!

We went to the southwest, sit-down Pasadita.  We didn't have as wonderful of an experience as we'd expected for Chicago Tribune's 2006 Top Taco.  The chorizo taco was very good, but the beef in my super burrito (which I got since the carne asada was the gauge for top taco) was so well-seasoned, I've wondered if they use Burger King's "grilling" method of chemicals.  I also had to spit out a lot of the unchewable stuff.  The burrito was big but also dry.  I guess we were supposed to use one of the three sauces they brought to the table.  However, two of them were too spicy to slather food in, and we'd eaten most of the pico de gallo with our chips.  They refilled the chips but not the pico de gallo--maybe we were supposed to ask for more?  I got a side of beans to add some moisture, and they were all right.  My  husband found his chile relleno and rice bland.  On a positive note, the service was prompt and efficient. Parking on the street wasn't a problem though the place was nearly full by 5 p.m. on Saturday.  It's a small place, and a group of four had to split up since the larger booths were taken.  Given the crowd, this might be a great place for some.  However, I prefer La Condesa a block away on the northeast corner of Augusta and Ashland.  It costs a little more, but the flavors are really wonderful.

Jesus tap-dancing Christ, this is real tasty Mexican food!  I must say during lunch this is a great place to hit.  No one turns it down.   However, I avoid it at dinner.  Living around the corner from this tells me that certain places are meant for certain people at certain times.  Know your limits, ese.

This place serves the best burritos and tacos in the area.  I'll typically stick with carne asada but I'll also get barbacoa tacos on occasion.  The ones I get are made with the traditional onions & cilantro though I do ask for cheese.  There's plenty of filling high-quality meat used for a very affordable price.  They also have orchata (a rice-based drink) which always hits the spot.

This has to be my favorite taco establishment in Chicago.  Go for the tacos carne asada without cheese and be sure to squeeze on the salsa verde.   Of the three restaurants this is the one just south of the Pizza Hut.

The tiniest and dirtiest of the three La Pasaditas...and also by far the best. The only reason to go here is for the carne asada tacos, but that's more than reason enough to head here again and again. The steak's grilled in front of you, and aside from squeeze bottles of excellent salsa verde on the countertop (there are no tables), the cilantro and onion on the tacos themselves is more than enough. Perfect, simple food. And very greasy. My one complaint is once you're done eating, you have absolutely nowhere to wash your hands. Not a big deal, but keep it in mind if you aren't getting the food to go.

not much to say except that these are the best tacos in chicago.  period.  if you are in the midwest, you are in the neighborhood.  three tacos de asada con cebolla y cilantro and a can of coke.  i used to make the drive from rogers park a few times a week, now thank the lord hey-zeus christo i can make a 5 minute drive or 15-20 minute walk.  when i grow up i want to marry la pasadita.
